Comments_List: General economic knowledge - supply and demand, imports, exports, price controls, and firm-based decision-making.
Microeconomics for public policy.
Basic knowledge of microeconomics

This course focused on some essential quantitative (applied) microeconomics skills and related policy concepts. This provided a broad introduction to me in economic thinking, micro basics, and connecting economics to policy design.
Collaborative learning skills, better ability to apply microeconomics, concepts to real world issues, and better ability to work out problems using calculus.
It seemed like a good intermediate level micro course. Developed micro more fully with calc.
I did get a basic and general overview of micro from the course, as well as the mathematical understanding of concepts.
Applications of economic intuition to real-life problems.

It seemed inconsistent throughout the course whether students should be focused on learning concepts or on being able to do specific math problems, which made it difficult to know how to approach studying. 

In Zach's lectures, he often seemed unsure of the material or seemed somewhat unprepared.
The concepts are broken down really well. The course could be improved by solving more practice problems in class.

I would have liked less of the basic concepts covered and a couple extra class periods delving into other intermediate concepts. However, since there were people without any econ background I understand why the early pace was there.

Strengths: I liked how the course sampled from across different aspects of micro.

Weakness/areas to improve: I personally learn best through math. I found tracking concept --> math very hard, as opposed to the other way around (math-->concept). A more integrated approach that spelled out the math and then connected it to concepts would have helped me greatly. I recognize, however, that not everyone learns this way. It's tough, because this is a class that will always polarize the students depending on how it's taught.

I also think that a different set of assumptions would help - while some students in the class are policy focused, I expect that all of us (or almost all of us) see the distinct value of economics in policy and everything else. I'm personally not policy-focused, and came to Jackson because I did want to study more economics. I chose Jackson because it gave me the freedom to do so, with all the other great benefits of the degree/Yale. Rethinking the assumption that we as Jackson students aren't interested in econ would help. I wanted to go into the subject more and was very keen to learn, and felt demotivated when I felt the class was being taught with the assumption that I was forced to be there and not interested.

The first part was great. The second part lacked structure. Furthermore, the instructor, as well as the other students, did not stay on the topic of discussion. I felt that the deviation from the classroom topics detracted from our learning experience.
The organization of the course and the Zac/Jim continuity/pass-over needs to be rethought, but apart from that - Yes.
Yes - the teachers are engaging and the course themes were interesting and policy-focused.
No.

No, I would not recommend this course. While the topic was interesting, and I learned some essential skills, the learning process was unnecessarily burdensome due to poor course design/execution. The problem sets were only of minimum value, particularly in the first half of the term, as they were hard to map onto the course notes and impossible to map onto our textbook (the textbook was terrible and did not add value to the course). A lot of the course material I self-taught by reviewing the instructors' notes and watching YouTube videos.
Yes I would because it helps you understand how to apply economics concepts to problem solving.
